title: Nissan reveals electric family car, the Ariya concept SUV, in Tokyo
text:
Nissan has unveiled its bold and powerful new all-electric Ariya family crossover that promises sports car levels of performance.

It is set to arrive in the UK in 2021 as a rival to Jaguar’s award-winning I-Pace and the Tesla Model-X, with a higher level of autonomous ‘hands-free’ driving technology onboard.

Expected to be priced from around £40,000 – but helped by a £3,500 taxpayer-funded green subsidy – it also signals the future design direction of the Japanese car giant and its other future models.

Coming to a showroom near you soon: Nissan hinted that the Ariya concept - first shown at the Tokyo Motor Show this week - will be on sale in the UK in 2021 for around £40,000

Without the need for a conventional petrol or diesel engine taking up space, and with batteries under the flat floor, the spacious new five-door battery-powered zero-emissions Ariya will be the bigger brother to the existing all-electric Nissan Leaf with a large lounge-like interior.

With its low roofline, Nissan design chiefs said the aim was to make cars that were ‘sleek and sexy’.

Powered by twin electric motors allowing all-wheel drive, Nissan says the Aroya promises sporty performance with speculation it will sprint from rest to 60mph in around five seconds, with a top speed of 155mph and a battery range comfortably in excess of 300 miles.

The dual front and rear electric motors deliver instant power to the wheels to supply ‘balanced, predictable power to all four wheels, equal or better than many premium sports cars’.

It promises ‘excellent cornering performance and traction on slippery surfaces’ - such as snow and loose dirt - without drivers needing to change their driving style, steering input or even pedal position, says the Japanese brand.

Although unveiled at the Tokyo show as a prototype or ‘concept’ the firm conceded that the electric crossover SUV was set to ‘make it into production in the near future’.

The Ariya features a V-shaped shield in place of the conventional grille, which is emblazoned with an illuminated Nissan emblem

The Japanese car-maker with a UK factory in Sunderland that currently builds the electric Leaf, Qashqai and Juke models and employs 6,500 people said the new Ariya also represented an entirely new design direction for Nissan.

Bosses said it ‘signals the dawn of a new era for Nissan’ with ‘a look that signals a complete reinvention of the brand’s design’.

This includes a prominent front V-shaped shield in place of the conventional grille, which is emblazoned with an illuminated Nissan emblem.

Nissan claims the car will have a top speed of 155mph but also a battery range comfortably in excess of 300 miles between charges

The car maker also promises award-winning driver assistance technology and the latest self-driving autonomous features to improve safety.

The Ariya has an upmarket interior ‘that feels more like a lounge than a conventional vehicle’, says Nissan.

The new car expands on elements in the Nissan IMx concept car shown two years ago at 2017 Tokyo Motor Show.

Nissan’s senior vice president of global design Alfonso Albaisa said: ‘We replaced the conventional grille with what we call a shield – an expressive piece with innovative 3-D texture within that goes beyond cosmetics. It also highlights the technology lurking within the vehicle.

‘In this case, it’s a radar sensor and other technologies that help the Ariya read the road and visualise things the driver can’t see.’

The Ariya concept already features the latest version of Nissan’s award-winning ProPILOT 2.0 driver assistance system that allows hands-off single-lane driving

He added: ‘It has proportions that show what’s possible with Nissan’s 100 per cent electric vehicle platform.’

The Ariya concept already features the latest version of Nissan’s award-winning ProPILOT 2.0 driver assistance system that allows hands-off single-lane driving.

Nissan says: ’By engaging the vehicle's navigation system to help manoeuvre the car on a predefined route on designated roads, the system can assist the driver with passing, lane diversions and lane exiting on multi-lane highways.

But drivers receive audio and visual warnings and prompts – such as when approaching a road diversion or preparing to pass another vehicle – when to put both their hands back on the steering wheel.

Drivers can also use a smartphone to park the car automatically.
